Follow the schedule provided in your orientation packet  January 30 Global Orientations: Italian Culture and Society - Follow the schedule provided in your orientation packet  January 31   Orientation Continues  January 27 - February 1 Freshmen and other returning academic year students may check in at any time during this period.  February 2 Classes begin  February 6 Classes meet on Monday schedule  February 16 Last day to drop/add courses.  February 23 Last day to drop courses and not receive a "W".  March 6 Last day to declare pass/fail grading option for a course for most students.    March 16 - 20 Spring Break  April 6 Italian Holiday (On Campus Offices Closed)  April 10 Last day to withdraw from a course (with a "W" on transcript).  For Gallatin, NYU Abu Dhabi, and Stern students: Last day to declare pass/fail grading option.  April 17 Italian Immersion Day (Follow your Italian Language Schedule)  May 1 Italian Holiday (On Campus Offices Closed)  May 7 Last day of Classes  May 11 - 14 Final Exams  May 15 All Students Check-out by 12 Noon      For information on tuition refund schedules and withdrawal procedures please visit the Policies and Procedures page .                Back to Top          Fall 2015*   August 24 LSP Freshmen Check-in  August 25 Undergraduate Check-in and Freshmen Convocation  August 26 All-Student Orientation  August 27 Global Orientations: Italian Culture and Society - Follow the schedule provided in your orientation packet             August 28 Global Orientations: Italian Culture and Society - Follow the schedule provided in your orientation packet      August 29 All Student Orientation Continues  August 31 First Day of Classes    September 14 Last day to drop/add courses.  September 21   Last day to drop courses and not receive a "W".  October 2 Last day to declare pass/fail grading option for a course for most students.  October 24 Alumni Day  October 26 - 29   Fall Break  November 6 Last day to withdraw from a course (with a "W" on transcript).  For Gallatin, NYU Abu Dhabi, and Stern students: Last day to declare pass/fail grading option.  November 6 Italian Immersion Day (Follow your Italian Language Schedule)    December 3 Last day of Classes  December 4 First Day of Final Exams (for Tuesday Courses)    December 8 Italian Holiday (On Campus Offices Closed)  December 7, 9, 10   Final Exams Continue (Monday, Wednesday and Thursday)    December 11 All Students Check-out by 12 Noon      For information on tuition refund schedules and withdrawal procedures please visit the Policies and Procedures page . February 1 Classes begin  February 5 Classes meet on Monday schedule  February 15 Last day to drop/add courses.  February 22 Last day to drop courses and not receive a "W".  March 4 Last day to declare pass/fail grading option for a course for most students.  March 14-18 Spring Break  TBA March or April   Italian Immersion Day (Follow your Italian Language Schedule)    March 28   Italian Holiday (On Campus Offices Closed)  April 8 Last day to withdraw from a course (with a "W" on transcript).  For Gallatin, NYU Abu Dhabi, and Stern students: Last day to declare pass/fail grading option.  April 25 Italian Holiday (On Campus Offices Closed)  May 6 Last Day of Classes.  Classes meet on Monday schedule  May 9-12 Final Exams  May 13 All Students Check-out by 12 Noon      * Please note that each semester there will be one additional Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday class meeting designated on the syllabus through either a required site visit, field trip, or academic lecture. All calendars are subject to change.          For information on tuition refund schedules and withdrawal procedures please visit the Policies and Procedures page . Admission will be granted only when space is available and time allows for required travel documents to be attained. Innovative, site-specific offerings in art history, history, literature and cinema are featured alongside a vibrant curriculum in sociology, politics and economics. These courses not only take advantage of the extraordinary cultural resources provided by the city of Florence, and its strategic position within Italy and Europe, but also of a unique array of co-curricular lectures and activities that make the Florence campus a dynamic center for scholarly exchange and global policy discussions.   What can study abroad in Florence mean to students? An encounter with the city of Dante, Petrarch and Boccaccio; direct examination of world-famous masterpieces of art in the "birthplace" of the Renaissance; to consider contemporary social issues at a campus where encounters for students with major European and American protagonists of world social and economic policy are a regular occurrence.   Throughout the year, students at NYU Florence benefit from the opportunity to participate directly in the high-level political, social and cultural policy dialogues organized on our campus. In previous years, we have hosted both Republican and Democrat presidential campaign managers, had a three-way dialogue with leading local Christian, Muslim and Jewish leaders, and held a student-organized contemporary poetry slam. Through La Pietra Dialogues, interested students also have the opportunity to participate directly in the organization of the events that bring these outstanding figures to NYU Florence.   NYU Florence provides the atmosphere of a small college campus while studying abroad. An extremely low student to faculty ratio ensures small class size; many courses are organized partly or entirely as seminars. Our 57-acre estate, with olive groves and gardens, has five villas that provide a home to NYU Florence. These include Villa La Pietra with its house museum, and formal gardens. Students enjoy the opportunity to "live" Villa La Pietra during: visits to the collection; poetry readings, concerts, performances and lectures that take place inside or in the gardens of the villa               Learn     Courses   Special Programs   Freshman Program   Facilities   Faculty   Community Service                 Live     Housing & Meals   Getting Around   Cost & Budgeting   Language   Culture & Customs   Safety   Health & Wellness     Staff                 Explore     Restaurants   Nightlife   Things to do   Local Travel   Regional Travel   Shopping                                                                       Info for Parents                                                                                                Info for External Advisers                                                                                                Visit Other NYU Global Centers                                                      La Pietra Dialogues LPD convenes some of the world’s foremost scholars, policy makers, practitioners, business leaders, public intellectuals and artists whose ideas and work have made a significant cultural or intellectual contribution to global society and the revival of the spirit of humanism for which Florence is known. They gather at Villa la Pietra, New York University's exceptional site in Florence, to confront some of the most intractable issues of contemporary society through the creative interplay of ideas and perspectives.  LPD fosters the creation of partnerships across disciplines, cultures and institutions, as an established center in the heart of Europe attached to an American university with branches throughout the world, and contributes to the emerging global civic discourse that is at the heart of NYU’s mission as a global network university. Bequeathed to NYU in 1994 by Sir Harold Acton, the Florentine study abroad campus consists of 5 historic villas and 57 acres of gardens and olive groves. Villa La Pietra, the Acton Collection, and the Garden are maintained as they were by the Acton family and serve as an inspiration to all who live and study on the campus.
